Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: An angry client is loudly criticising a cut moments before the salon is due to close.
Situation2: They notice a minor ethical dilemma at work, like someone cutting in line, and feel a mild urge to act.
Story:
The clock on the salon wall ticked closer to closing time as I swept up the last of the hair clippings. Just then, a client stormed out of the chair, her voice rising above the hum of the dryers. “This is not what I asked for!” she shouted, glaring at her reflection. My training as a hairdresser told me to stay calm, listen, and do whatever I could to make her happy, even if it meant staying late. My coworkers glanced over, anxious to leave, but I knew I couldn’t ignore her complaint.

As I tried to soothe her, I noticed another customer quietly slipping ahead in the line to pay, bypassing someone who had been waiting patiently. My heart twinged. As a Hindu, I was taught to uphold dharma—righteousness and fairness—even in small moments. I felt the urge to speak up, to gently point out the unfairness, but the angry client demanded my full attention. Torn between my duty to my client and my moral responsibility, I felt the weight of both roles pressing in, unsure which voice to listen to first.
